title: NLPGo: Better research through better tools
segmentation: OK, so I manage the artificial intelligence lab at Bloomberg in New York.
In fact, when I say New York Bloomberg is a global company, so the lab actually spans both Europe and the US.

And we're about 20 people and where 20 people who are interested in taking not only the wealth of information that's available to Bloomberg as a news and financial economic data powerhouse in general, but interesting information from any modality, right?
Whether it's textual information.

Whether it's images, whether it's speech segments, whether it's structured information from databases around the world, ontological information from knowledge bases, and doing interesting things at the intersection of that being able to pull together these structures to find patterns to identify relationships that exist between them and to somehow make it useful both for Bloomberg clients but also.
Through that journey, by identifying areas that are interesting and patterns that might be valuable.

We've identified areas where there is the possibility of improvements for research work, where we might be able to do better science when we are informed by the kinds of decisions being made by engineers.

And therefore to be able to harness one of the best of both worlds in order to create a better environment in which to innovate and in which to provide the kinds of technologies and algorithmic facilities that are important to all of us.
So.
This is a slide that I show pretty frequently, along with my presentations.
It's really a schematic diagram of what my group works on and in the middle we have this search for a representation of knowledge that exists out there.
Right and outside?
We're looking at different ways in which we can transform the information available to us into this knowledge.
How do we find the links that are most important?
Well, first of all, we work a lot with natural language processing.

We want to turn the textual information held in news and government releases and press releases in the way that the legal world talks in the way that information is presented on the web into something that we can all explore and understand, and that involves many compositional elements that come together to allow you to build these cohesive structures.
At the top, you have things like.
The ability to learn structure right?
So a syntactic pass of a sentence is some kind of graph that represents the structure of that sentence, and it has semantic anchoring that tell you what different roles things are playing within it.
You can take that a step further and you can talk about actual explicit representations of knowledge.
Such as in ontologies, such as in distributional frameworks, for the representation of relationships among concepts.
And we want to kind of bring these full circles.

In this particular talk, what I want to show you is how we took a set of conversations and the work that we've been doing over the past four or five years, and decided that there were issues in the way that scientific research was being carried out, and that there are potentially better strategies that we can help to inform them that we can help people to build on.
So actually, Interestingly enough.

We were at a conference around a year ago with Estevam and Tom and many other people, and we started talking about some of the biggest difficulties that we have as researchers in being able to produce consistent results.
Being able to share what we've done with people, being able to build on top of it and extend it, and also.
Difficulty with which we bring together the community of researchers in artificial intelligence around machine learning and natural language processing and computer vision.
And how do we incentivize people to share more to come together more often and to build a vision of how these technologies can work together in future?
Because ultimately it's all well and good, if me.
And Andrew and Shafayat and other people in my group are working on solving a core problem in natural language processing.
And then we have 1000 other people globally working on exactly the same problem in natural language processing.
And I believe that you know I'm going to do this by myself because I'm better equipped than everybody else to do it.
Well, it's simply not true.
Most of the time.
Most of the time I would be much better off.
I would save myself time, energy.

I would find a better solution if I harness the work of everybody and I allow them to bring it together in a way that makes sense to provide the right incentive mechanisms to get people working together.

So I'm going to give some anecdotal evidence about why I think this is necessary, and I've been doing the rounds in various continents trying to persuade people that we have an issue here and that we think we have a way to address some of these problems, and then we're going to show you one particular project that.
We are very excited to be releasing today really in its beta form and in front of you guys that will help to stop kind of set the seeds for these kinds of collaborations in future.
We're going to go over what this framework is.
How it's going to benefit different classes of users that might be interested in using it?
And also I'm going to hand it off then to Andrew, who is kind of one of our main architects of this particular system.

And let him show you the benefits of it, concretely by actually giving you some examples and showing you why we use it and why we think it's it's going to be a good foundation for the AI community generally.
So this all started by thinking a little bit about, at least on my end.
How we solve problems as human beings, right?

One of the things that got me interested in artificial intelligence many years ago was the feeling that as humans, we don't necessarily have hugely complex mechanisms of solving problems or of breaking down what we're looking at and making more sense out of it.
In fact, these are usually fairly simple modules that get composed into things that then.
From a higher level, look to be sophisticated, so wouldn't it be great?

If we learned to have a framework that would allow us to breakdown these situations that we observe into the components that make the most sense to be able to analyze them both initially in terms of identifying what objectives we have with respect to them.
But also then analytically and in a statistical framework afterwards to be able to understand how the sets of decision-making processes and algorithms that we've used in our head actually map.
Onto an ability to solve a problem right?
How do we evaluate what we've done and how do we form it into an entire cycle that allows us to get better overtime, right?
And we need that framework in order to be able to do these things, we need to be able to question what we're doing.
We need to be able to understand what assumptions we're making and how they fit into this framework.

We have to have conclusions that are properly drawn from the data that are available, and a representation that makes sense given the problems that we're attacking and given the objectives that we have.
So.

One experiment that I did a few months ago was to take the research that we have been looking at as a research group and we generate a lot of papers ourselves and we consume a lot of the research that's out there at the at the forefront of the state of the art and conferences, and from the collaborations that we have.

And often we find ourselves in the situation where we are impressed by the work that somebody does for their PhD or in a research lab in academia or in another company, and we want to be able to replicate it.
So we'll take the paper and often will know the people that we're working with them well.

We'll try to get to the point where we can use these same algorithms to do our own experiments and to push forward our own research and maybe even eventually to build better products that our clients will want to use.
By using this research.
It's only a small sample.
I've taken 12 paper.
From the past four years or so that we looked at and what I tried to do was understand the flow of activity that happened within my team while we were trying to reproduce these results and use them.
So what we're looking at here is the variance from the published results that were achieved on the papers that we looked at.
So these are papers from all across AI.
They include knowledge based population, 2 named entity disambiguation, summarization and even things.
More basic things like tokenization and parts of speech tagging.
And as you can see, we have a high variance, right?
We have some papers where.

We achieved close to what was reported on the same datasets using supposedly the same methodologies, but then we have many papers, more than half of the papers where we're not close to the results that were reported and we have one paper strangely enough, where we actually do better than was reported in the paper.
But that's something that is extraordinarily rare.
I think that's a tail event that we've got there.
So then we actually go back and we talk to these people right?

And we get their code and we get their data and we get the pre processing steps that they went through and we talked to their PhD students who have long gone into industry in far flung places of the universe.

And we see, well, what can we do now that we have more information and we've really dedicated additional effort to doing this, so I don't know how well you can see these graphics, 'cause it looks like they've been a bit distorted by the projector, but most of the time.
Still, we can't replicate the results and we don't know why.
Right, including when we have access to the original code that supposedly provided the results that were presented at these prestigious conferences.
So that to me seems to be a problem.
Right?
And not only that, but then let's take the scenario where.
I manage a group of 20 people and these 20 people need to remain motivated.
They need to be able to solve problems and they have many tasks that they could focus their time on.
Right, so I want to know when I dedicate some portion of the resources that we have available for the year towards replicating this research that's out there.
How much does that actually take, right?
How much time am I taking away from something else that we could be looking at?
And the results are kind of discouraging because.
We can take up to five weeks of time in terms of working days.
To not be able to solve the problem.
Right, and this isn't something that's unique to my group, right?
We're not.
It's not that we're dumb, and maybe we are, but at least we've seen evidence in other research groups across both industry and academia where the same thing happens.
We see the same pattern repeating itself over and over again.
People are spending disproportionate amounts of time on tasks that we should have moved beyond having difficulties with, right?
We're all smart people.
We have objectives, and we have agendas for our research.
We want to write great papers.

We want to publish research that really builds on the frontiers, and yet we spend most of our time building bash scripts that do come data conversions from one schema to another or cleaning the datasets or obtaining the datasets or trying to understand why our test set is not giving us the same results as the same algorithm on a different person's computer.
Well.
It would be great if we didn't have to do.
That if we didn't have to deal with this problem.
So.
We said about after these conversations with people who work in this area and a lot of nodding an agreement and.

Identifying that something needed to be done to actually coming up with a strategy that might be able to help us get from the situation that we're in to a better place for doing research and our key components for this, our core objectives were that we wanted to encourage the ability of researchers to reproduce each other's work.
Right, we want to remove the overhead or the burden that people associate with being able to take somebody else's work and reproduce it as it was stated.

We want to make it extensible, so we want to be able to quickly take what other people have done when they've contributed it and be able to not only verify that it does what it says on the tin, but actually then change it and experiment with it in ways that were not previously done and therefore to build on top of it.

We want to be able to measure what we're doing at all times, so we want to compartmentalize the test that we're doing to the extent where we understand the performance of every single component within this system.
And we can therefore, as scientists understand, how each contributes to the broader message that we're trying to pull together and to the research that we're trying to create.
We want it to be usable because.

A lot of frameworks that have stated that they wanted to do this kind of thing in the past have not necessarily caught on as globally as we might have liked, not because their core libraries were not efficient enough and not because they didn't provide the facilities that people needed, but because they were not easy to pick up off the shelf install and work with without modifying the normal workflow that people use, right?

Everybody works in slightly different ways, but when you adapt to doing something that has marginal incentives that are good for the whole community, you should not have to sacrifice very much for your own productivity when doing that.
That's actually a core tenant of anything.
If we want it to be adopted, is that for you?
It should be seamless right behind the scenes.
We could have done things that are extraordinarily complex, but when you see it, it should be a turnkey solution.
And the final part, and maybe the most important part is you can only build a community if you're prepared to share.

So we want to build the incentive mechanisms and bring people together both through events like this and what we're doing tomorrow, but also broader outreach and really setting a standard for what's necessary in the Community.
And encouraging people to buy into that vision.
So we want to be able to make research compositional extendable and we want people to live in an environment where it's easy to innovate, right?
And as a research group we had this problem.
We had a problem where you have big libraries and you're scared to make changes to them.
You start to build kind of a jungle of code out there in the real world and.

Then you get to a point where marginal improvements have a high cost, even if it's just a cognitive burden in getting started and we want to remove that cost from the equation so that people can just get going on solving things and playing around and getting back to being intellectually curious.
So what is our framework?
Our framework is called NLP go and that's.
A play on a Bloomberg ISM, a Bloomberg ISM, which goes back about 30 years.
So we're a company that for the longest time.
Believe that in order to do anything well, it had to be done in-house and only in house, right?
So kind of not quite what I've been telling you so far, so we started making our own keyboards.

And our own keyboards had their own labels for the buttons and they were colored differently depending upon what you wanted to do and some of some of that keyboard and some of the functionality is extraordinarily useful for people in finance, area and economics.
One of the I think maybe least necessary features of this keyboard is that there is no enter key.
There is a key that has the word go on it.
But there's no enter key, so whenever we run anything within this huge environment for the finance industry to do their work and for using data and analyzing it and manipulating it.
We type in the monarch, which is the same as a URL, and then we hit go.
So everything in our environment is a word followed by go.
So NLP go is our framework for doing natural language processing and that's the only thing that we expect you all to take as an assumption and not question.

Everything else is up for grabs, so NLP go was developed as a set of C libraries that are core to being able to achieve the task that I mentioned, their quarter being able to breakdown problems into key components.
Their quarter being able to achieve natural language and AI processing tasks seamlessly and compositionally.
They allow for things like scalable computing.
So how do we thread things and make them parallel?
We allow for different kinds of dependencies that algorithms might have.
So if I'm calculating named entities, I would usually want features taken from parts of speech tags from chunks from tokens from the languages that we identify.
Right, so I don't want to build an algorithm that meshes all of those things together unless it really needs to.
I want to build algorithms that allow you to compose from it, and in this sense it's very much the same ideas you might find in a framework like UIMA.

Now these hierarchical algorithm dependencies which make the whole process modular also have to be in as far as possible, automatically computed by the system, so that when I'm designing a new system, if I don't need to know about it, I don't need to worry about specifying how it happens.
It should also not contribute any additional overhead.
This is having a set of bash scripts and piping one into the other.
If you wanted to do it manually.
And that's extraordinarily important, because you need to come to trust that the system is not doing things that you don't expect it to.
It's simple, right?
I mentioned it has to be easy to use, otherwise none of you will use it.
And honestly, we won't use it if it's not easy to use.
So we can write the best software in the world.
But if the interfaces don't make you want to come back to it over and over and over again, then we failed.
And they also because a lot of people in this community.
Unfortunately.
Use Java.
Although it's in C++, it needs to also be able to handle other languages that.
People who were not fortunate enough to become indoctrinated with C++ have fallen into.

So because of that we want to handle the ability to go across the whole community regardless of whether people want to write in Python, in Matlab, in Lisp, in J, or you know, whatever you feel like doing.
So internally we want it to be flexible.

We want the document object model the way that these things are passed around to be intuitive and to be easy to understand, both from somebody reading the code to somebody actually talking about it in a normal conversational setting when doing research.

And most importantly, for building the community, we want this to be filled right with fully supported, fully maintained state of the art algorithms for achieving the core sets of tasks that need to be achieved in this area.
And that's important because.
We want researchers, practitioners, and anybody else that has work in this area to be able to come on board and use it straight away.
So although you can imagine people contributing all kinds of things, there will always be a core that is fully maintained.
Which is built by expert engineers and maintained by them to provide the state of the art and then you can also think of it as a challenge.
Wouldn't it be nice if you can say that your named entity recognition algorithm is the one that is used by the Community by default?
Red so this is what we do, kind of in essence, within our framework.
And Andrew is actually going to break it down.
Much further than that, I'm going to give you a little bit of a pitch for each of the stakeholders.
Why this is something that we think is needed and why this is something that we think is useful.
Right, so one is that we do want to provide a community resource for AI.
And that means that we're not doing this for Bloomberg, right?
In fact, to me that was the opposite of where these conversations started.
The conversations did not start as we are an industrial partner in research collaborations and what is the best way for us to quickly get a technological win from our research funding?
Right, although obviously we want our research funding to go as far as possible and to get people excited about research and to contribute into real products.
This is actually about addressing core problems in the community that we've identified.
We want to be able to easily reproduce these results.

As I, as I mentioned, easily extend an experiment with them, but also to offer this common evaluation platform where if you put something in it's transparent to everybody else what you've achieved right?

If the datasets are openly available through common evaluation, kind of benchmarks in conferences or through other ways that we get corpora and the algorithms are present, then everything will work as advertised throughout this entire pipeline, it will work across all of your different.
Systems it will.
It will compile properly.
It will run correctly and you'll be able to get going on the task that you really wanted to achieve much more quickly.
And as I mentioned, we need to evaluate.
We need to be able to use it across different languages because the research community hasn't centered on one specific way of doing things.
But we want to bridge the gap to the practitioner community as well, right?
And that doesn't necessarily mean my group, because there are other groups within Bloomberg that actually take these technologies and push them into products more aggressively than we do.
And we want to make sure that they, though maybe less of a foundational research group, are capable of picking these things up and using them to their full capability.
Right, and that means having the state of the art algorithms inside, right?
That's a lot of effort from our end, but it's also effort from the research community to want to have their things be part of this.
It has to be robust and scalable.
That means that the code that we write has to be at an enterprise level.
It cannot be academic code, it has to be code that is going to run in a production environment that is capable of understanding what is going on and making the best use of resources, right?
Which is why we have people like Sheffied and Andrew working on this code as opposed to myself.
We need to provide transparency into the research efforts that are happening.
Right, we need to be able to give people an idea of what the latest and greatest things are.
Right, and why we're doing them?
And build messaging and maybe even build a better PR engine around all of the tasks that were doing so that people don't come out and tell us that we are an evil community, right?
That's maybe something that we can also look at.

We can also make sure that we provide ongoing support because again, one of the reasons that many of these sister projects or previous attempts at a similar vein of research or system provision have failed because they don't necessarily get supported to the full extent that they should, and they therefore don't build the community to the full extent that they could.
So encouraging
Back and forth between industry and academia, and these different research pockets and people who actually use this stuff.
Now, what else could we actually do with it?
So we are having a wonderful dinner last night.
Ann and Tom and Steve.
I'm actually came up with more ideas than than I had come up with in the past.
And you know why don't we think about whether we can use this framework in a teaching setting, right?
Encourage people to get to grips with it, encourage competition and encourage people getting together.
So Junior had an idea earlier today that we can maybe incentivize both sides of this right where we have a common framework that people can use to collaborate.
And to compete.
To build the best possible solutions for a particular problem.
You want to be able to hack with it.
You want to be able to do things really quickly, right?
And that applies to anybody.
People who are complete novices in the area of artificial intelligence and natural language processing, and people who are seasoned and want to try something different.

And maybe we can even get it to be used as a submission system for one of the conferences as a common way of representing the work that gets done, whether that's for an initial kind of specific track at first, or for something a little more substantial.
But these are areas that we can.
We can explore.
The biggest part of this is that we want to make sure that NLP go is and will remain.
Open.
Extensible.
And also friendly people will actually want to work with it and will keep putting their items into it.
So.
Brain is actually the the informal name of our research lab.
And.
Brain is Bloomberg's research efforts in artificial intelligence.
And so the brain lab is these 20 or so people that work across London and New York in my group.
And we as a group.

Right outside of everything else, fully committed and behind this project, and so we've put in a lot of effort over the past year or two to build something that we are extraordinarily proud of, but that we're also looking to continue to make better over the years.
And there are many unanswered questions, and there are many things that we're going to be improving on.
But this is our first opportunity to show people outside of our core areas.
What the internals of this system actually look like and how useful it could be to the community as a whole.
So.
We do want to build this community and.

One of the reasons we came here first was because not only do we have a lot of friendly faces and a lot of good connections here, but we have fantastic researchers and fantastic students that I think could benefit a lot from the work that we've done and who can benefit us a lot with their feedback and kind of their thinking.
And there using the tools that we've built.

So this is really the first time that we're showing this to anybody, and you're kind of our beta community, so I want to make sure that we start off on the right foot and we give you everything you need to feel excited that this might be something that helps you work faster and smarter and helps you feel more connected to what's going on.

And I'd also like to make sure that you're aware of an event that we're having tomorrow, where if you wear, if you provide us with your GitHub username, will actually give you the full repository way ahead of when we're doing the public release and we will work with you.
Kind of one on one to try and hack some stuff up tomorrow that will make you get some hands-on experience with this.

Right, and we use this software at Bloomberg and we're building our technology on top of this, so we hope that you'll also want to build your technology on top of this and that you're sharing this vision with us in.
Future.
So having said that, I'm now going to pass it over to Andrew and we're going to dive into kind of the really guts of this system and its full capabilities.
And where we're going with it.
I'll leave it over to that.
Feel free to reach out to me at any point.
Drop down my email address and we'll be happy to be in touch with you.

Identifying that something needed to be done to actually coming up with a strategy that might be able to help us get from the situation that we're in to a better place for doing research and our key components for this, our core objectives were that we wanted to encourage the ability of researchers to reproduce each other's work.
Right, we want to remove the overhead or the burden that people associate with being able to take somebody else's work and reproduce it as it was stated.

We want to make it extensible, so we want to be able to quickly take what other people have done when they've contributed it and be able to not only verify that it does what it says on the tin, but actually then change it and experiment with it in ways that were not previously done and therefore to build on top of it.

We want to be able to measure what we're doing at all times, so we want to compartmentalize the test that we're doing to the extent where we understand the performance of every single component within this system.
And we can therefore, as scientists understand, how each contributes to the broader message that we're trying to pull together and to the research that we're trying to create.
We want it to be usable because.

A lot of frameworks that have stated that they wanted to do this kind of thing in the past have not necessarily caught on as globally as we might have liked, not because their core libraries were not efficient enough and not because they didn't provide the facilities that people needed, but because they were not easy to pick up off the shelf install and work with without modifying the normal workflow that people use, right?

Everybody works in slightly different ways, but when you adapt to doing something that has marginal incentives that are good for the whole community, you should not have to sacrifice very much for your own productivity when doing that.

Our framework is called NLP go and that's.
A play on a Bloomberg ISM, a Bloomberg ISM, which goes back about 30 years.

Believe that in order to do anything well, it had to be done in-house and only in house, right?

And our own keyboards had their own labels for the buttons and they were colored differently depending upon what you wanted to do and some of some of that keyboard and some of the functionality is extraordinarily useful for people in finance, area and economics.
One of the I think maybe least necessary features of this keyboard is that there is no enter key.
There is a key that has the word go on it.
But there's no enter key, so whenever we run anything within this huge environment for the finance industry to do their work and for using data and analyzing it and manipulating it.
We type in the monarch, which is the same as a URL, and then we hit go.
So everything in our environment is a word followed by go.
So NLP go is our framework for doing natural language processing and that's the only thing that we expect you all to take as an assumption and not question.

Everything else is up for grabs, so NLP go was developed as a set of C libraries that are core to being able to achieve the task that I mentioned, their quarter being able to breakdown problems into key components.
Their quarter being able to achieve natural language and AI processing tasks seamlessly and compositionally.
They allow for things like scalable computing.
So how do we thread things and make them parallel?
We allow for different kinds of dependencies that algorithms might have.
So if I'm calculating named entities, I would usually want features taken from parts of speech tags from chunks from tokens from the languages that we identify.
Right, so I don't want to build an algorithm that meshes all of those things together unless it really needs to.
I want to build algorithms that allow you to compose from it, and in this sense it's very much the same ideas you might find in a framework like UIMA.

Now these hierarchical algorithm dependencies which make the whole process modular also have to be in as far as possible, automatically computed by the system, so that when I'm designing a new system, if I don't need to know about it, I don't need to worry about specifying how it happens.

This is having a set of bash scripts and piping one into the other.
